posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked:
We are having trouble crimping our own DuPont connectors. We got the crimper and connectors through AndyMark’s website and we watched many tutorial videos. We got 3 working but that’s after a total of 10 times (30% success rate) which obviously is not going to cut it.

We experience the following issues

Bent connector ends after crimping

Insulator ends too fat to push through

cannot push through in general

We are using these because we were having issues with the WAGO 221 connectors with the small CAN bus wire. would soldering them be better? Does anyone have any tips? Are we doing something wrong?

posts.name: Kaan Beldağ
posts.cooked:
ebear11:

WAGO 221

Can you say the serial number for wago?

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Please post photos showing the symptoms you described. Please also post photos ora video of how you are using the tool.

posts.name: Cody Wellman
posts.cooked: The ends of the connector should not be getting bent by just crimping them. By insulator ends too fat, are you talking about the insulation of the wire is too thick? What wire gauge are you using? 22 AWG 1000V has too thick of insulation for example it would be best to use 300V wire. I have zero issues with 22 AWG 300V wire.

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: I cannot send any pictures or videos till later today but I will certainly do so as we have a lot of those connectors now and we do not want to waste them. As for the fat comment, I mean the metal insulator crimp seems to stick out just enough so that we cannot push it in. I will send a photo later today to add on to the post.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked: Bent connector end in my experience usually happens either if the insulation is too thick, or the connector was inserted in the crimping tool wrong (the crimper die is not exactly symmetrical). If you post a closeup of the wire with the terminal inserted into the crimping tool, may be we can see something. Video would be helpful as well. I never had issues crimping standard CAN wire, but I had issues crimping some of the red/black pairs at times where the insulation was a bit too thick for the gauge.

posts.name: Leo
posts.cooked:
Both crimping and soldering are going to be a lot better then using WAGOs, it really just depends how well you do either of them. Personally, 3128 is switching from wagos to soldering all of our CAN this year.

If you want to go down the crimping route, a slightly better alternative to the crimp connects on Andymark are Molex SL connectors, they are a similar form factor/size, but have a locking mechanism to keep them from falling apart. More about them in the Mechanical Advantage build thread from this past year:

FRC 6328 Mechanical Advantage 2023 Build Thread Open Alliance

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
leo-les:

More about them in the Mechanical Advantage build thread from this past year

Thanks for the shout-out!  Be sure to also read this post - we really like Molex SL’s and have had great results with them, but using the right tool for crimping is a big part of that success.

We also posted a video of how to use the Molex tool to make a good crimp.

I talked with the Molex rep at Worlds and he thought they would have a program in the coming season to make this crimp tool more available to teams, but details have not been announced AFAIK.

Feel free to reach out with any questions.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Those tiny pins are super tricky to crimp right.

You MUST have wire gauge in the right range.  You MUST have the insulation thickness in the right range.  You have to get the strip length right ± maybe 0.2mm.  You have to get the pin in the crimper in the right position (pulled against the step between the insulation crimping area and the wire crimping area.  You have to have the right size crimping nest for your pins.

The crimper has to have two areas in it; the insulation crimp is designed to be larger than the wire crimping area. If your crimper doesn’t have those two sections, it won’t work right. If you have the pin backwards in the crimper it won’t work right. If the pin is upside down or sideways it REALLY won’t work right.

Yes, I can do them reliably.  I found that carefully trained students could deliver a robot with about 50% of the crimps not conducting electricity at all.  You need hair tearingly high levels of perfect on the strip and the procedures to do these right.  At least that’s my opinion, supported by having to completely re-do an entire robot’s CAN bus…

Keep in mind that there are teams that are VERY successful with these connectors.  My team was not one of those.  We love CAN lever nuts

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
Weldingrod1:

We love CAN lever nuts

I post a link to these in pretty much any CAN connector thread I come across. Absolutely love the CAN lever nuts from WCP .

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
leo-les:

Both crimping and soldering are going to be a lot better then using WAGOs

Based on what metric?

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
leo-les:

Both crimping and soldering are going to be a lot better then using WAGOs

I don’t agree with that - the Wagos when used with the specified sizes are very reliable in my experience.  If you’re really concerned about them opening as you grabbing inside the robot, a small piece of heat shrink tape around the body is cheap insurance.  I think I’ve used them about 100 times and done the heat shrink tape thing maybe twice when connectors ended up close to the battery and we wanted to make sure that no heroic manual actions when changing the battery in the vicinity would impact our wiring.

Crimping is virtually all about using the right tool (and avoiding the bottom dollar pins - it’s a real hassle because many of the ones you find on places like Amazon are just bottom dollar junk - I have no idea how to separate the good from the bad pre-purchase but I’ve thrown pins away that were nothing but trouble and have a pretty generous surplus of housings which even the cheap folks tend to get right).  Most “Dupont” style connectors are some generic clone and crimping them properly can be a pain even with decent multi-stage crimpers.  In many cases, I fall back to my trusty Engineer PA-09 manual crimpers using a two step process with one step for the wire and the second for the insulation.  If you go this route, be sure to get the legit Made in Japan models and not some clone (it’s getting hard to tell but with Amazon, you can easily return it).  Beware if the name of the tool is some variant like “Engineers” - that almost certainly is going to be a clone or questionable quality.  They may be doing some manufacturing in Taiwan now but I’ve got the original MIJ versions and they are super solid.

Soldering is almost always the least desirable and reliable alternative due to temperature and flexibility concerns.  I’m pretty sure you can build a really good FRC robot and never solder anything wiring-wise (putting things like custom PCBs and the like aside).  None of the FRC -mandate components need solder connections so it’s generally a good idea to avoid bring them in where you don’t need them.

As other folks have mentioned, the Dupont connectors are very sensitive to wire size and insulation size for a good crimp.  The jump from Duponts for smaller wires and APPs for larger wires has a wiring size gap - I find the Wagos cover that very well and have a really broad range of wire size compatibility which is very helpful and cuts down on the number of connectors you need to worry about.    The WCP lever nuts mentioned are solid as well in my experience.

In general, the Duponts needs some care and attention to be successful - I have generally good results but student-applied crimps seem to be a little itchier…

posts.name: Jim Smith
posts.cooked: We use JST connectors because they latch together. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07QKBKNC1/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&th=1 Crimping is going to be similarly challenging. It is definitely a skill that takes some practice. T-Taps are an option. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07GXJ46K7/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&th=1 What ever solution you land on think about the scenarios of removing a motor from the loop, troubleshooting, or swapping a motor during a 2 match cycle.

To be clear, it seems you’re using (knockoff) JST-SM connectors, which is a locking wire-to-wire 2.50mm pitch connector series. JST makes many other connector styles. Their wikipedia page even says

The term “JST” is sometimes incorrectly used as a vernacular term meaning any small white electrical connector mounted on PCBs.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Ok, your tool is not crimping that properly.  The little fangs on the insulation crimp are should be turned and fanged into the insulation. Right now they are just snugged up.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
Weldingrod1:

Those tiny pins are super tricky to crimp right.

If using generic tools, I agree.  But using the dedicated tool-for-the-job does solve most of the problems you list.  As long as you use genuine parts (we buy Molex-brand contacts and shells from reputable electrical suppliers (DigiKey, Sager, or similar), right size wire for the contacts, and strip appropriately, the tool handles all the holding and aligning and produces a good crimp in one go.

Using generic crimpers is possible but requires a lot more time, effort, and focus.  It’s enough harder that I’m not sure we’d be using the SL connectors as much, if at all, if that’s all we still had.

Weldingrod1:

You have to get the strip length right ± maybe 0.2mm.

I don’t think the strip tolerance is quite that tight.  An easy approach is to overstrip wires slightly and then trim to length with diagonal cutters (preferably in pairs so the lengths stay the same).  We found the students could eyeball it well enough with a little practice.

Weldingrod1:

I found that carefully trained students could deliver a robot with about 50% of the crimps not conducting electricity at all.

I can only imagine the frustration.  Sorry to hear you had that experience.

Our experience was much more positive.  Between CAN, encoder (extended) and LED connections, we had several hundred of these crimps on the 2023 robot.  Students working on them were really good about self-inspecting (and asking a mentor to check if needed); I don’t recall having any issues that we traced to bad SL crimps.  But as always YMMV and it will depend a lot on the particular students doing the work.  I always encourage teams to use the methods that work for them.  Just because we like Molex SL doesn’t mean it’s right for everyone.

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: Good news! We used another pair of crimpers that has a better variety of sizes and I can reliably crimp them now! Thank you for all your help!

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Further to what @Weldingrod1 stated. Connectors like these are really meant to be assembled using automated machinery for high volume manufacturing environments. That is where your “PWM” cables come from. In places I have worked we had the capability to make prototypes using such connectors and would switch to outside contractors with the machinery to do the high volume work once the design was proven.

I have been responsible for the electrical training on the teams I have mentored over the last 10 years. I have found that we got the best results when we invite students who have demonstrated that they are consistently meticulous and careful when doing other work such as mechanical construction. The skills such as how to use a crimper can be taught. It is very difficult to teach someone to be meticulous and careful.

In the places I work, those assembly line workers only those who are meticulous and careful would get to work on the wiring looms and circuit boards. Those who are not are sent to do the less critical mechanical assembly jobs.

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked:
zog:

Engineer PA-09

We are switching from WAGO connectors because we found they are cutting the small gauge CAN bus wire. With higher gauge power wires they are not an issue so we will keep using them for those applications. We got the DuPont connectors working but my team opted to use spade connectors instead of our DuPont connectors because the DuPont connectors take a lot of time to do even though we can do them reliably now. Spade connectors take a generic crimper and we could even just use pliers and they are much faster to crimp. We are trying to rewire our CAN before the BoilerBot 2023 competition that we are taking part in. so speed is of the essence.

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Ok, your tool is not crimping that properly.  The little fangs on the insulation crimp are should be turned and fanged into the insulation. 
Right now they are just snugged up.
